description.text:
This was heavily inspired by the other brain gear shared here on Thingiverse. The other brain gears I've seen are printed all-at-once by a printer with soluable support material or such. I redesigned everything from the ground up such that it can be printed on my (hopefully coming soon) Makerbot. Assembly might not be possible and I'm thinking there will probably be some breakage.
I'll try to update and get rid of some of the bugs when I get my printer in.
You'll need to print 12 of the BG-1, 4 of the BG-2, 1 of the BG-3, and 1 of the BG-4-A (Assembly of the 12 necessary sleeves).

comments.text: An update:  the bearings that slip into the gears print with a hole too small to fit the frame pieces.  The frame arms that hold the gears appear to be 0.24" diameter, but the bearing parts come out with holes about 0.22".  I'm using Slic3r.
comments.author: treborg999

comments.text: I'm printing this.  Gears and other parts are doing OK, but the baseplate came out warped across one direction (the orthogonal direction is flat).  This is the surface sitting on the bed.  I'm running a bed temperature of 110 deg C.  is that too hot?
comments.author: treborg999

comments.text: does this work?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It works in Pro/Engineer when I designed it. That being said, I added a little bit of gapping in the meshing of the teeth because from FDM'd parts I've had printed professionally in the past, they don't necessarily hold tight tolerances. Also, I have nearly convinced myself it isn't possible to assemble completely and you might need some room to push the gears around to get the final BG-2 to fit and hold everything together.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: I like this a lot! I think it'll print okay -- I'll give it a shot soon on my MakerBot Cupcake. Is there any particular part you want printed first?
comments.author: dmatsumoto

comments.text: Wow! You're brave! It's a LOT of time and material to get one of these fully printed and assembled. I don't even really know where to start, but you might try doing all the parts except the gears and try to assemble to frame. If the frame assembles, I'm sure the gears will manage fairly well.
comments.author: dmatsumoto

description.text:
Enclosure for the Beagleboard-xM
  • Super Thin! 91x93x27mm
  • Perfect fit! Our board was designed using real measures.
  • Beautiful design with rounded corners.
  • TrollScience Inspired! Use magnets for closing (ala SmartCover)
  • Can be adapted to be wearable.
    • You can donate some money to the next Paypal address: [email protected] Designed in Catia v5

[UPDATE] V1.1 Revision! 1) Print both parts and 2 units of the "Switch" model, which are used for pressing the buttons. 2) Insert the two switches in the TOP part, placing them from inside. 3) Place you Beagleboard-xM inside the bottom part, and close the box. Enjoy! For Closing Purposes: 4) Place small magnets on the small holes on both parts. There are 3 holes per part, located on the front and left sides of the box. Seal the holes with glue. You can acquire the magnets by harvesting inside old broken CD/DVD drives. I found mines to be strong enough for the box! You can also add some shielding for the magnets by first painting the holes with "metallic paint" before sealing them. This provides more protection from damaging the board.

description.text:
A simple lampshade that fits on standard light fixtures with 30 mm washer. The model was made in Cinema 4D using the cogwheel tool for the shade fitting and a cylinder primitive deformed with the taper tool. The surface features were made using the MoExtrude function under the MoGraph menu.

Please refer to the video for assembling instructions.

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVhgFdhvntg

By Creative Tools

Home - Things - #3DBenchy - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Pinterest - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

Notes:

Please refer to the video for assembling instructions.

The lampshade is provided in two versions.

  • Solid: To print this, please slice the model with no top or bottom layers and if possible use the vase mode in your 3D printing software. If you choose to print in standard mode (no-vase-mode) you can define the thickness of the shade by adjusting the perimeter shell count.

  • Thin-walled: This version can be used in most slicers. The thin membrane (0.5 mm) will only make room for one perimeter.

title: Filament Spool Holder for box style printers (with Aluminium-Profile)

description.text:
You can mount this holder to an vertical extrusion at the back of your printer to hold a role of filament. And a second one for the second Extruder. And a third one for the spare-role.

SCAD-file:
You can sutomize nearly everything to fit your preferences and printer-setup.

STL-file:
I used filament-roles that are 9cm wide.
The STL-file fits for 20mm aluminium profiles and M5 screws.

EDIT:
Added a calculation for having the desired wall-thickness in endcone regardless of extreme values of overhang angle.
Thanks to Jan for helping me with this.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

CL-260A

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40

Notes:

I used a 0.2 layer hight (because i print everything with that),
with a 40% infill for a bit extra strength.

If you really want a sharp-edged endcone on this, i recommend using support-material. On my printer i can made this with 40° without support material, so i set this as default-value.

I printed my version without the endcone, but with a endplate. By change the endcone-overhang to the desired angle, you can customize this model in another way.
I had to remember simple school-mathematics for calculating the translation-distance of the inner (substracted) cone. Greetings Pythagoras!

Mapping Tool - BCN

It is a multipurpose kit for the gathering, processing and data visualization in the old fashion way.

It´s simply, download the file, open it at your graphic program, and send it to your laser cutter.

Just remenber, in the dxf file you will find 4 layer, called: Streets, Neighborhood, Districs, and Contour.

The layers Streets, Neighborhood, and Districs are for being engraved; and the layer Contour is for being cutted on the cork.

You will also find a layer called Caps, and this one is for cutting the mdf. You will get two big circles and two small circles, using glue, stick one big and one small, and this pieces are going to work as caps for the cardboard tube.

• Cork sheet of 915mm. x 610mm. x 5mm.
  • Mdf sheet of 300mm. x 300mm.
  • Transparent mica sheet of 610mm. x 800mm.
  • Cardboard tube with an inner diameter of 100mm
  • Glue
  • Markers, tacks, ropes, ect.

title: FrSky D4R/X4R mount with tilting antenna (for imrc Vortex and others)

description.text:
After I damaged one antenna of my receiver, i was looking for reasonable receiver mount.
While searching for a suitable solution for my immersionRC vortex I was not really happy 100% with either thing I found.
Therefore I have created this very simple and lightweight combination of those designes I liked most.

Yet another Receiver holder that fits for Frsky D4R-II and X4R-Receivers snuggly.
The actual antenna part can be tilted for easy transportation. The swivel-mechanism also helps in case of a crash.
Fits both on my vortex 285 and vortex 250 pro. Most likely other vehicles as well...

BoM:

2 pieces of 3mm antenna tubes with 100mm length
1 M3x30mm (Nylon) screw
1 M3 nut

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dr7TRi2FNh6

print_settings.Notes:: 25% infill makes this case pretty solid. I don't think you would need any more. As with all press-fit applications, your printer has to be tuned well in order for this to work. Otherwise, you may need to do some light sanding to the inside of the cover to make it fit properly.

title: Travel case for Canon LP-E8 batteries and SD cards (Canon T2i/T3i/T4i/T5i)

description.text:
This case holds 4 LP-E8 batteries and 3 sd cards. I designed it for an upcoming trip I'm taking where I need quite a bit of battery capacity and storage. The top is a press fit, and there are cutouts to accommodate the terminals and tabs on the batteries for a nice, tight fit.

I wouldn't recommend putting the top on this case without batteries installed, though. The batteries keep the top from going on too far. It's very hard to get the top off if you push it all the way on with no batteries installed. The best way I found to do it is to stick a metal spatula between the top and bottom on one end of the box and pry the spatula left and right. Switch sides and repeat until the top comes off.

I have included a plated version of the top and bottom for your convenience.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

25% infill makes this case pretty solid. I don't think you would need any more. As with all press-fit applications, your printer has to be tuned well in order for this to work. Otherwise, you may need to do some light sanding to the inside of the cover to make it fit properly.

This is for all those people like me who really like the fan-mount from the Hugo project, but really REALLY hate those little flimsy pieces of plastic that you're supposed to slide under your extruder. They're way too thin. So I designed this beefier one-piece replacement. It does require you take your extruder completely off, but that is better than replacing those plastic peices over and over again.
Anyway, enjoy!!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/35p6X4apnbW
DNA chain

Cover needs support.
Use
-90mm 12V computer fan for cooling, (assembly hole axis distances should be 82,5mm typ)
-12 pcs M3x16 or M3x20 bolts,
-4 pcs M3 nuts,
-4pcs M3 washer
for assembly.

Cover may require support.

Before use; please check the Z-axis limit switch trigger is not touching the fan while moving along the Z-axis. (it only have 1-2mm clearance between them)

author: brandonkolybaba

description.text:
This is a modified Raspberry M12 cam case of thing 467182 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:467182) to fit into BCN3D Sigma 3D printer. Cam direction is optimized to see the whole printing bed on every level. I have used cam with M12 lens because the field of view is optimal for usage inside the Sigma frame. Beside this the M12 lens has the possibility to adjust the focus. The cam is connected to my Raspberry where i have installed Octoprint to remote control the Sigma.

To fit the cam i recommend to use double-sided tape.
For the case you need M3 (countersunk). For longer M3 screws you need to drill the whole (2,5mm) deeper.

comments.text:
Hi, do you have more specs on the cam? E.g. where to get the model you are using with your case.
Where do you store the Pi at? Did you fit it in the printer?
comments.author: makeasec

comments.text: Hi, search on eBay for "raspberry M12x0.5" (e.g. seller: electronics_lee). This is the one i am using. The field-of-view from this lens is the best to see the whole printing bed from the Sigma. I have tried lot of other rpi cams but this one was the best for this used case. You can use longer flat cable to put the raspberry to the bottom inside the Sigma. I am also powering the rpi from the Sigma mainboard (do this on your own risk). I am using this setup now for more than one year without any issue.

title: Mendel90 E3D Titan complete extruder mount

description.text:
Complete and tested conversion kit for the E3D Titan extruder on the Mendel90

Accomondates a 20mmx15mm radial fan for all you cooling needs :D

Printed the first version in Alloy910 and wasn't thrilled about the high elasticity. I did another run with PLA and ran with that for a time before I finally settled with some carbon fiber PLA

Update: Made cooling duct 1mm longer to better clear the hotend block, made cut in extruder mounting bracket larger for wiring with pin headers.
Update 2: Added real life pics of extruder
Update 3: created mounting point for fan on fan duct
Update 4: Small adjustment to some sizes, replaced some fillets to make for easier printing.
Update 5: Added Solidworks sources

The latest version of this titan carriage has been under heavy use for the past months and proved very successful.
Pleas note, that i wrapped my extruder in kapton with air pockets to avoid getting hit by deflected cooling air. Without that your temperature reading can momentarily fluctuate.

Step Files can be provided if requested

comments.text: I'm wondering if this will fit my Mendelmax 1.5, what is the rod spacing on the Mendel90 and are those 8mm bearings?
comments.author: Ma_tits

comments.text: Hey,
comments.author: Ma_tits

comments.text: Hey, somewhat off topic question. Which microswitches did you use for the endstops? The only actual part number reference I can find is from an old forum post Nophead made in which he references a part not available in the US. What I'm seeing is that 99% of the endstop switches available are the ones mounted on pcbs which obviously won't work. It's the only major hang up I'm having with this build.
comments.author: hodgeac

comments.text: its worth noting that the fan and duct should be mounted before fitting the extruder to the carriage. Fantastic design, the best always are the ones which just work, thank you!

comments.text: My fan is 50x50, too. For it to fit however, it also needs an outlet that is 20x15mm in size. It should fit, but to be sure, I'd recommend that you check with your supplier.

I like having the cooling duct on the side, the 60mm fan duct in the original design is really bulky. I'll let you know how it turns out.

A 445nm 1.7W laser upgrade to the popular MakerBot 3D printer. Turn your 3D printer into an instant laser cutter! It cuts plastic, hobby balsa wood, paper, foam board, vinyl, and engraves many more materials. Check out the details at http://laser-bot.com Laser Cutting Solder Stencils Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Gaz_gt1olM Laser Cutting Wood Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQkePnhR8JA

This is an upgrade to the MakerBot Thing-o-Matic 3D printer. First you must purchase the laser upgrade kit from J Tech Photonics. Then print out the holder and connector piece. It uses two M3x20 screws to attach the laser to the holder and 2 M4x25 screws to attach the laser holder to the connector pieces. The connector pieces go under the extruder assembly and use the thumb screws that are already there. So, the basic instructions are as follows:

  • Get laser upgrade kit: http://jtechphotonics.com/?product=1-7w-445nm-laser-diode-and-2-0-amp-adjustable-driver-kit

  • Print out the Laser Holder, and MakerBot Connector pieces.

  • Attach the aluminum laser housing to the Laser Holder piece with two M3x20 screws and nuts.

  • Take off the thumb screws under the extruder and place the printed connector pieces under the extruder and replace the thumb screw through the connector piece. Do this for both sides.

  • Place the Laser Holder under the two connector pieces and use two M4x25 screws (or whatever you have around that fits) and nuts and tighten. Do this for both sides.

  • Attach a cable to the heated build platform "motor control" pins and connect to the TTL input of the laser driver board.

  • Attach a cable to the laser driver board output to the laser connections. Red is + and black is -.

  • Plug in the laser board with the adapter.

  • Modify your G Code files with the M106 "laser on" and M107 "laser off" command. Replace M03 with M106 and M05 with M107.

  • Place something on the platform so you don't ruin it. We used an old CD case lid. It fits right on top of the aluminum build platform on the MakerBot. Or you can use some thick plywood cut to size.

  • Focus the laser and set 0,0 coordinates.

  • Press Build! You have a functioning laser cutter!
    • Remember to use the appropriate safety goggles and safety requirements. This is a project and is using high power lasers. You are responsible and liable for all damages or injury. Use caution. Check out more details at http://laser-bot.com and our blog at http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=52

comments.text: Can this be used with a replicator 2?
comments.author: MattFarrell

comments.text:
Yes, Replicator 2 can be upgraded. We have had many people successfully upgrade this machine and their mounts are available on Thingiverse as well. Check out the instructions here:
http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=1702
You will need to use M126 to turn the laser on and M127 to turn it off. You will unfortunately not have PWM control due to limitations in the Sailfish firmware.
comments.author: MattFarrell

comments.text: What do you mean by "you will not have PWM control? I'm new to this. I want to be able to cut and engrave stuff.
comments.author: jtechphotonics

comments.text: PWM = Pulse Width Modulation.  Essentially it allows you to do a laser power setting between 0-255.  With the Rep 2 it will be only on/off rather than #% power...
comments.author: MattFarrell

comments.text: So in other words I can't do the fancy picture engraving stuff that is shown in the video (car being etched)
comments.author: RaMcHiP

comments.text: Correct :(.  Unless you replace your motherboard which is my plan!  There is currently a user working on it through the fans but I do not think he will get there without firmware modification.
comments.author: MattFarrell

comments.text: anything for replicator 2x?
comments.author: hyppyayo

comments.text:
anything?
how could i wire it with mightyboard rev.H?
comments.author: hyppyayo

comments.text: Yes, it works with Replicator 2x (REV G and H Board). The connector J11 (Fan_Cool) is controllable via G Code. Connect the + pin and - pin from the mighty board connector to the laser driver terminal H2. You turn ON the laser with M126 and turn it OFF with M127. This should work with all the firmware versions. Check out the instructions here for more details: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=1702
comments.author: hyppyayo

comments.text: Would this work with a Flashforge Creator X Printer?
comments.author: SirKhaal

comments.text:
Yes! Fellow maker ramchip has made a mount for the printer. It is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:472126
There is a controllable EXTRA output on the mightyboard as well as an extra output that you can use to get the driver working. Just make sure your FET is there... Check out here for more details: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=1713
comments.author: SirKhaal

comments.text: Will this cut acrylic?
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text:
Yes! The 2.8W kit can cut acrylic a lot faster now. Most will cut at about 50 mm/min with about three passes. Some acrylics will be faster and some slower. Check out the blog post here for a full write-up: http://jtechphotonics.com/?p=1648
Video is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NV5NWtxTdn4
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: I'm new to 3d printing and considering getting a Velleman K8200 3D printer as it has a good max print size and the price is right. Can i upgrade it to laser cut with this kit?
comments.author: norgmonster

comments.text: I believe you can. It has a fan output on the control board which you can swap to the laser driver input to control the laser. Use the M106 command to turn it on and M107 command to turn it off. You will need to make a mechanical mount for the laser. The complete implementation instructions are located on the website here: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=1016http://jtechphotonics.com/?pag...
comments.author: norgmonster

comments.text: Does this work on a solidoodle too?
comments.author: aaronboo

comments.text: I looked at this a bit more and it will be easier to upgrade the solidoodle by swapping out the fan on the control board and use it for the input to the laser driver. Use the M106 command to turn "on" the laser and the M107 command to turn "off" the laser. You will also still need to make a mechanical mount for the laser. The complete instructions are on the website at: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=980http://jtechphotonics.com/?pag...
comments.author: aaronboo

comments.text: With the solidoodle 3, using the fan connector, is it solely on/off or can it engrave pictures?
comments.author: jtechphotonics

comments.text: It depends on your hardware/firmware combo for your machine.  It should be able to have PWM control for engraving pictures, but I would check first.  Hook up a fan to the board and in your Repetier control software under the "manual" tab, move the fan slider down a bit and see if the fan turns slower.  You can alternatively run a quick program using M106 S125 command to see if the fan goes to half speed and then toggle it to M106 255 to see if it goes back to full speed.  You can put a G0 P2000 between the two commands to pause for 2 seconds so you can tell the difference.  Either way, it is best to check if you have hopes of engraving images.
comments.author: diyengineer253

comments.text: I believe so. Their software still runs a basic G Code program (or you can install replicator G as shown in their FAQ page). All you need to do is jumper over the extruder motor wires (motor forward and ground wires) to the input of the laser driver. You can then either draw your laser cuts in a 3D program but only make them 2D, export to .STL and do the normal process you would with a 3D object or you can use the inkscape program and plugin on http://www.laser-bot.comwww.laser-bot.com to get the G Code output directly from your 2D drawing.
comments.author: aaronboo

comments.text: The J Tech link has an extra http:// attached at the beginning, you may want to fix that.  It wouldn't work at first, then I realized what was wrong.
comments.author: Frowney001

comments.text: Thanks for finding that error!  Fixed.   :)
comments.author: Frowney001

comments.text: What are the materials that have been confirmed to be safe to cut.  Can you do acrylic?
comments.author: RaMcHiP

comments.text:
With the 2.8W laser kit at 1.5amps (2.2W), 3mm acrylic can cut at a feedrate of 50 mm/min with three passes. Z depth decrease 0.6mm per pass.
Other materials for cutting include paper, fabric, balsa wood, basswood, foam, etc... application page is here: http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=1177http://jtechphotonics.com/?pag...
comments.author: RaMcHiP

comments.text: Would this work with a Replicator 1 Printer?
comments.author: sengelking

comments.text: @sengelking - Long story short, it should work. I just looked at the documentation at the http://makerbot.commakerbot.com support site and it looks like they still use a version of the heated build platform with the extra pins on the connector for motor control, which you then convert to the laser control with the M106, M107 commands. I have never used the "makerware" software, but it says you can use Replicator G as well on the Replicator 1, which can process your G Code files with the modifications for the laser control. It is worth a try with a volt meter to check the output of the pins on the heater board while you switch the output. In my replicator G software there is a button on the control panel that says "build platform belt" that you can enable/disable to switch the output on these pins. Otherwise, there is a FET output on the mightyboard that you can use. You might also need to design another mount for it to attach to the extruder, but this should not be hard.
comments.author: sengelking

comments.text: Please don't cut vinyl with your laser! It releases chlorine gas that can not only damage your laser optics but can damage people too.
comments.author: EngrainedProducts

comments.text: Would this work with an Afinia H-Series Printer?
comments.author: JGraf82

comments.text: I just looked at the printer manual and I don't think it can be modified very easily, if at all.  It is a nice printer though!  The MakerBot Thing-o-matic and RepRap printers rely on G Code files which you can modify for the laser.  Also, it looks like this printer does not have any extra outputs for the laser control.
comments.author: JGraf82

comments.text:
have you tried it on plywood?
would be interested to mount it onto my ultimaker... :-)
comments.author: drayson

comments.text: You can engrave very well on plywood but it won't cut.  If you want to cut plywood you will need a much bigger laser like a 80W CO2.  People are making very nice engraved pictures, art, and engraved names/logos on thicker hardwoods with the kit though.
comments.author: drayson

comments.text:
I totally agree with the goggles. It took some time to find ones that are a reasonable price and to source them, but now they are here! http://jtechphotonics.com/?product=laser-safety-goggles-for-445nm-lasershttp://jtechphotonics.com/?pro...
Not the most stylish ones out there, but just $19.99!
comments.author: jtechphotonics

comments.text: It probably would be a good idea to sell safety googles in your shop as well.
comments.author: talpa

This is a vortex amplifier, a fluidic element for amplifying a fluidic signal. 
The supply flow(flow going straight into the circle) can be modulated by weaker control flow(flow going 
tangent to the circle) by the control flow inducing a vortex in the chamber. 
This vortex increase the resistance to flow, thus amplifying the signal from the control flow. 
In short, apply flow to the control flow port and there will be less flow coming out of the output port.

Print both Vortex_amplifier.stl and Vortex_Plate.stl and bolt together tightly with M5 screws. If you're having trouble with leakage, cut a piece of double stick tape to shape and put it between the plates. Or if you're feeling more adventurous, print it as one piece by printing Vortex_amp_assem.stl. Connect to other fluidic elements using 5/16" tubing. Now if you want to do something really cool, run this device with water and don't put anything on the output port(center port), you should now have a jet, now apply pressure to the control flow port, the jet at the output port should turn CONICAL! It should look something like this: http://fritopia.info/page1/topic_pages/stuff_I_made/fluidics/vortex_diode/vortex_side.JPG http://fritopia.info/page1/topic_pages/stuff_I_made/fluidics/vortex_diode/vortex_front.JPG http://fritopia.info/page1/topic_pages/stuff_I_made/fluidics/vortex_diode/vortex_rear.JPG Now hook up a fluidic oscillator to your control port and you should be able to make a small one of these: http://www.tippettsfountains.com/jetspray.php

comments.text: Guys, stop posting Mickey Mouse science ... Before you can claim that this device acts as an amplifier, you have to show that the principle works. There is no amplification here.
comments.author: albertfolch

comments.text: Of course there is. Do a little research before accusing people. Vortex amps are well-understood commercially available devices used in industry. For example, see: http://nuvisioneng.com/Portals/0/ProductProfiles/Legacy/VXA.pdf
comments.author: albertfolch

comments.text:
Pages 7-9 here give a rough overview of how these devices work:
http://books.google.com/books?id=5beGAAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA9&ots=GOVB0-m-Nr&dq=fluidic%20vortex%20amplifier%20pressure%20gain&pg=PA7#v=onepage&q&f=false
comments.author: albertfolch

Attention! The metal plate on the rear of the SSR is very hot at high currents, so this part should not be used for high current ratings.

comments.text:
Nice design.
Just keep in mind that for higher currents, the metal back side of the SSR serves as a heat dissipater. This 3d printed part would block the heat transfer.
This might not be a problem for low currents, but put a fuse in the circuit to prevent misuse by others who don't know about this issue.

How can you innovate common everyday products with 3D printing? that is the question students are trying to answer when they participate in this competition style project. Students are asked to pick a products and think of a creative way to redesign it. How they do this is totally up to the students. If you want to see creativity and innovation from your students, this project will bring it out. This give them the opportunity to have design freedom and demonstrate their creative while still demonstrating their 3D design skills, their engineering design process knowledge, and teamwork. Check out my website for an example of how this project works: http://goo.gl/nprp2D There are a few example models posted with this project: One is a bowl redesigned to look like a shark, complete with a fish spoon, another is a set of dice with actual braille numbers, the last model is a bracelet that is designed to help you locate headache relieving pressure points. These are just examples, your students will create a wide variety of designs. No 2 products should be the same!!!!
The designs will be totally up to the students. Let them demonstrate their creativity.

Project Name

Innovate 3D Competition

Overview and Background

Students will be able to apply their knowledge of 3D design/printing, the engineering design process, and 3D printing in this project. Teachers always look for ways to let their students demonstrate their creativity and this project is a great way to do it.

Objectives

-Utilize 3D printing to redesign a common product.
-Demonstrate an understanding of 3D modeling and 3D printing.
-Apply the engineering design process to design a product.
-Brainstorm ideas.
-Create technical drawings with dimensions, multiple views, labels, etc.
-Evaluate and redesign a product.

Audiences

This project was originally designed for middle school students. The class that originally complete this project was a 7th Grade Technology Education Class.

The difficulty of this project could be adjusted for elementary or high school students.

Students should have some background with the design program before completing this project.

Subjects

This project was originally designed for a Technology Education course but it could be used in a variety of classes.

Skills Learned/Standards 
Develop an understanding of the attributes of design.* (ITEA, STL 8)
Evaluate and modify designs and products created to solve a problem and explain how one solution can cause other problems. (VSC Science/Skills and Processes/Technology)
Explain that requirements for a design are made up of criteria and constraints. (ITEA, STL 8-G)
Develop an understanding of engineering design.* (ITEA, STL 9)
Define brainstorming as a group problem-solving design process in which each person in the group presents ideas.

TE.IaI.09.02 Explain that design involves a set of steps, which can be performed in different sequences and repeated as needed. (ITEA, STL 9-F)
Explain that modeling, testing, evaluating, and modifying are used to transform ideas into practical solutions. (ITEA, STL 9-H)
Develop abilities to apply the design process.* (ITEA, STL 11)
Define the problem.
Brainstorm Possible Solutions.
Generate Ideas.
Research Ideas/Explore Possibilities.
Specify Constraints and Identify Criteria.
Consider Alternative Solutions.
Select An Approach.
Develop Written Design Proposal.
Make Model/Prototype.
Test and Evaluate
Refine and Improve.

Lesson/Activity

Project Summary:
Students will work in teams of 2 to compete in the Innovate 3D competition. This competition asks students to utilize 3D printing to innovate common, everyday products. Students can pick any product to work on, as long as it is simple and school appropriate. The students are trying to improve the product in some way using 3D printing. They can choose to make a product more ergonomic, change the look of a product, add features to a product, or improve it in another way. It is up to the students to determine how to improve the product. Students will work through the design process to develop their products.
Before the products are printed, the class will vote on the designs. Each team will present their 3D model and try to convince the class that their design is the most original and creative. The students will decide the top 3 most creative and original designs from each class. The in class voting is the “preliminary round.” The top 3 from each class will be printed first and will move on to the final round.
During the final round, the 10-15 finalists will be displayed with their descriptions in the media center. The final round will be open for voting to students, teachers, admin, and anyone else who goes through the media center. The finalists designs (not student names) will also be shared on a website with a link to the voting page. So anyone who has the link will be able to see the designs, read the descriptions and vote on the designs. This opens up the voting to even more people and gives the students a wider audience.
At the end of the voting period, the winner will be announced. The 1st place team will earn the title of 3D Innovators of the Year.

Major Student Products:
Design process log.
3D computer model and technical drawing
Presentation to class (students decide how they want to present)
Daily log (quick questions at the end of each class about what they accomplished, what challenges they encountered, etc.)

Timeline:
Introduce the Innovate 3D Competition. Show students the website and answer questions about the competition. Explain the preliminary and final rounds of the competition. An example site is posted here.
Students begin working with their partner to pick a product and determine how they are going to use 3D printing to improve their product.
Students will continue working on their designs. When they have decided on a design they will create a technical drawing.
When the technical drawing is complete, students will check in with the teacher. The teacher will give feedback on the student designs and make sure they are designing with 3D printing in mind. Once students have feedback from the teacher, they will begin creating their 3D models.
When 3D models are complete, students will determine how they are going to “sell” their product to the class. They can choose how they will do this.
Students will vote on the top 3 designs in each class. This is the preliminary round.
The top 3 designs from each class will be printed and displayed in the media center and online. Teachers, students, admin, and others online can vote in the final round.
When voting closes the results will be shared with the students and the people who voted. The top team will earn the title of "3D Innovators of the Year."

Duration

This project took about 4-5 47 minute periods for students to design and create their 3D models.

Preparation

Students should have some experience with the 3D modeling program that you choose to use. They should also have an understanding of how the 3D printer actually works. Students should have some background knowledge with the engineering design process as well. if they do not have this background knowledge, teach them as a part of this project!

Assessment

Major Student Products:

  1. Design process log.- Students keep track of each step off the design process that they complete. For my students this is not the first time they have used the design process so they are assessed on their ability to complete each step of the design process.

  2. 3D computer model and technical drawing-Students create a technical drawing (they have previously learned about these) and a 3D model. Their drawings are assessed on quality and accuracy. the models are assessed on their readiness for 3D printing, and their accuracy.

  3. Presentation to class (students decide how they want to present)- Students give a short presentation to "sell" their designs to the class.

  4. Daily log (quick questions at the end of each class about what they accomplished, what challenges they encountered, etc.)-This is a quick 3 question form at the end of each period. It further assesses the student's knowledge of the design process and 3D printing.
Handouts and Assets

I created a website to go along with this project. This made it easy to share the details and the finalists with the students and other people. The example website is here: http://innovate3d.weebly.com/

comments.text: My 3d printer does not start from top to bottom just printe on side and up. How can I change it to print to side to up.
comments.author: eliotnes30

comments.text: Not sure if this is the answer you are looking for, but depending on the software you are using there should be a Object Placement feature to which you can reorient the model for how you want it to print. So if you want to print the file on its side you would have to load the Object STL then before slicing it Rotate it on the various x y z axis. After you rotate just make sure that it is laid flat so it's placement is not floating above the print bed. This will help in situations where you want less support material or from having a face side of a object as the first layer. I have to do this for some models myself as I sometimes use a thicker first layer for better adhesion which doesn't look to good.

title: MPCNC z nut lock for trapezoidal spindle

description.text:
Remixed http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790533 from Allted and modified IE_z_nut_lock_13mm.stl for a trapezoidal nut.

You need a well adjusted printer to print this part and depending on the elasticity of your filament, it might be difficult to get the nut in the nut lock without breaking the nut lock.

I used this parts:

  • 1 x 5x8mm flexible motor coupler
  • 1 x addititional 608 ZZ bearing for anti backlash
  • 3 x TR8x1.5 nut 17x15mm (two for anti backlash and one for the z nut lock)
  • 1 x TR8x1.5 trapezoidal spindle 8mm x 400mm
  • 2 x DIN 988 8mm x 12mm x 0.5mm spacers

Part order from top to bottom: Coupler, spacer, bearing (within z_motor_mount), bearing, spacer, 3 x nut.
Tight the two top nuts against each other to fix their position on the spindle.

I made a copy of the original drive gears in my push mower after the original ones stopped working. I've made them with PLA and they seem sturdy enough. Couldn't believe, a) how crude the design is, b) how this bit seems doomed to wear out so quickly, c) how impossible it is to get replacements.

Moteur Stirling gamma - Kit 2 - Engine Stirling in kit

Le kit présenté permet de réaliser un moteur Stirling ludique sur le principe d'un Légo composé principalement de pièces imprimées, de récupération de boites alimentaires classiques et de quelques composants du commerce.
Particularité du kit 2 :

  • L'assemblage n'est pas figé à une dimension, il s'adapte aux boites récupérées.
  • Le sous ensemble vilebrequin et volant d'inertie est réglable, on peut choisir la course du piston et régler l'inertie du volant.
    Voir la Documentation dans « téléchargement ».
    Pour un premier essai , imprimer seulement les pièces conseillées dans la documentation.
    Vidéo :
    https://youtu.be/p66OsTgjHlM

Pour une réalisation voir aussi les préconisations du KIT 1

Engine Stirling gamma - KIT2-
The presented kit allows to realize a playful engine Stirling on the principle of Légo consisted mainly of printed rooms(parts,plays), recovery(recycling) of classic food boxes and of some components of the business(trade).
Peculiarity of the kit 2:

  • The assembly is not congealed in a dimension(size), it adapts itself to the collected boxes.
  • Under set(group) brace and steering wheel of slowness is adjustable, we can choose the running(race) of the piston(valve) and settle(adjust) the slowness of the steering wheel.
    See the Documentation in "download".
    For a first try(essay), print only rooms(parts,plays) advised(recommended) in the documentation.

For a realization see also the recommendations of the KIT 1

title: Han In Carbonite (HIC) Printable Control Panel Base

description.text:
While there is another HIC control panel on thingiverse that is more detailed i found it next to impossible to print on a regular reprap. Instead I designed these from scratch in scetchup. Note they are 97% of full size, as my HIC prop was just a tad smaller, but that is generally not noticable and they print really well.  
You will still need to back the covers with aluminium plates and add all the grebblies,  I will add these later as I make them  
The cut up parts are scaled to print on a mendel with a print bed approximately 20x20cm and print in a reasonable time. remember you need 8 of them.

comments.text: what are the overall dimensions of the parts i'm looking to scale it down for a project.
